title: 108_s2205
content: There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so the curr_chunk cannot be summarized. The Congress acknowledges that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate without excessive taxes or charges, has been compliant with freedom of emigration requirements since 1997, and has made significant progress towards democracy since gaining independence in 1991. Since gaining independence in 1991, Ukraine has made significant progress towards democracy and a free-market economy. As a member of the OSCE, Ukraine is committed to developing governance in line with human rights principles outlined in the Helsinki Final Act. Ukraine has also shown progress in meeting the requirements for freedom of emigration since 1997. Ukraine has made progress in meeting international commitments and standards in recent elections, despite shortcomings in implementing election laws and allegations of interference and intimidation. Ukraine, as a participating state of the OSCE, is committed to addressing issues related to national and religious minorities. Legislation has been enacted to protect against incitement to violence based on discrimination, including anti-Semitism. Ukraine has also committed to ensuring freedom of religion and combating racial and ethnic discrimination. Ukraine has made efforts to combat ethnic and religious intolerance by cooperating with US NGOs and restoring religious properties confiscated from minorities during the Soviet era. Ukraine is working on developing a legislative framework to revive minority groups, has normal trade relations with the US since 1992, and is progressing towards joining the World Trade Organization. Ukraine is addressing various trade issues, such as access to US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, and customs reform. Additionally, Ukraine has implemented labor rights protections but still has gaps in enforcement. Ukraine is also a member of the OSCE. Ukraine, as a member of the OSCE, has committed to upholding freedom of the press despite ongoing infringements. The country aims for European integration, democracy, and prosperity for its citizens. Ukraine has also collaborated with the United States in peacekeeping operations in Europe. Ukraine has participated in peacekeeping operations in Europe and cooperated in the global fight against terrorism with the United States. Termination of application of Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Ukraine. The President may determine that Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 should no longer apply to Ukraine and proclaim the extension of permanent normal trade relations treatment to Ukrainian products. The President may terminate the application of Title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 to Ukraine, allowing for the extension of permanent normal trade relations treatment to Ukrainian products. The Sense of Congress is stated in Section 3. The United States Congress emphasizes the importance of engaging with Ukraine, urging them to fulfill commitments such as free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, and combating discrimination and violence. The United States Congress emphasizes engaging with Ukraine to combat discrimination and violence, expand restitution of religious properties, and respect media freedoms. They also support Ukraine's efforts to improve in various areas. The United States Congress supports Ukraine in enacting and enforcing intellectual property rights, resolving trade disputes quickly, and monitoring human rights and media freedoms. They also provide assistance to NGOs and human rights groups. The United States Congress supports Ukraine by providing assistance to NGOs and human rights groups involved in activities related to human rights, democracy, and rule of law. They aim to establish annual discussions with Ukraine on these issues, involving both American and Ukrainian NGOs. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 requires reports to assess issues outlined in section 3(1), and rights under the 1992 Bilateral Trade Agreement will continue to be enjoyed. The 1992 Bilateral Trade Agreement between the US and Ukraine remains in force, providing the US with rights to use safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine. Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974 applies to Ukraine as it does to China as long as the trade agreement is in force. SEC. 6. EXERCISE OF CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT OVER WTO ACCESSION NEGOTIATIONS. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report detailing the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced in Congress within 30 days, it will be considered. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A resolution of disapproval introduced in Congress within 30 days will be considered. The term "resolution of disapproval" refers to a joint resolution by Congress stating that the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession does not adequately serve US interests. The resolution must be introduced within 30 days of the agreement, with the President notifying Congress within 5 days of the agreement. Resolutions of disapproval must be introduced within an appropriate date. In the House of Representatives, any Member can introduce them, and they are referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Rules. Resolutions may not be amended by either Committee. In the Senate, resolutions of disapproval may be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Finance, and may not be amended. The provisions of subsections (c) through (f) of section 152 of the Trade Act of 1974 apply to Committee discharge and floor consideration. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions regarding committee discharge and floor consideration apply to resolutions of disapproval in the House and Senate. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate are enacted as an exercise of their rulemaking power. The Trade Act of 1974 provisions allow for committee discharge and floor consideration of resolutions of disapproval in the House and Senate. The rules of each House are part of their respective rules and can supersede other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures.
